assumptions.text: AI agents (Claude Code, Cursor, Code-puppy, etc.) will respect bootstrap files like CLAUDE.md and .cursorrules
File-based artifacts are more durable than agent memory for long-running projects
ELCS can be implemented progressively (Level 0 â†’ Level 4) without breaking earlier levels
Unique terminology (WorkToken, CognitiveCone, etc.) will prevent confusion with other methodologies
The EAR methodology (used to build ELCS) is sufficient to complete this project

hypotheses.claim: Multi-entry bootstrap (CLAUDE.md + .cursorrules + .windsurfrules) will work across 3+ agent environments
hypotheses.falsification: If any major agent environment ignores all bootstrap files, this hypothesis is falsified

hypotheses.claim: ELCS protocol can be followed by agents without custom tooling (pure file-based)
hypotheses.falsification: If agents require custom tools/APIs to follow ELCS, this hypothesis is falsified

hypotheses.claim: WorkToken-based coordination will enable emergent multi-agent collaboration
hypotheses.falsification: If token claiming leads to deadlocks or no coordination improvement, this hypothesis is falsified

evidence.summary: Code-puppy and Claude Code both read claude.md/CLAUDE.md files at session start
EAR template (epistemic-agentic-runtime-main) successfully persists state across sessions via files
EAR 12-stage pipeline has guided this project from idea through scaffolding successfully

hard.text: ELCS must work with any agent that can read/write files
hard.rationale: Tool-agnostic is a core design goal

hard.text: All ELCS artifacts must be human-readable (no binary formats)
Template must not require installation or dependencies to use

soft.text: Prefer JSON for structured data, Markdown for prose

soft.rationale: Agents more likely to read short files completely

preferences.text: Progressive disclosure (simple by default, depth on demand)
